Indispensable advice for Newbies:

-The most important thing in rocket design is to get as much thrust as possible. Burn until you are out of fuel, and let momentum carry you up into orbit.

-If your rocket struggles to make orbit, adding more fuel is the most efficient way to fix the problem.

-Always remember your parachutes for a landing on the Mun. They will make your descent much easier.

-Spaceplanes are the simplest part of the game. You shouldn't even think about dabbling with rockets until you have fully mastered spaceplanes.

-If you are experiencing lag, add more struts to your rocket. Lots of wobbling puts strain on your processor.

Kerbals build everything springy. One can achieve escape velocity simply by firing a brace of boosters downwards to compress them. Once the boosters are shed, your rocket will leap skywards and soon leave Kerbin behind.
Eve is one of the easiest places to go to and get back from. You should really try it!

To save weight, do not put any ladders on your Eve and Tylo landers.

Best method of landing is an agressive lithobraking with your engines.

NERVA's are only engines spaceplanes need.

Mainsails are only engines any rocket needs.

Put wings and aerodynamic control surfaces on every stage of your ship.

- Never press "T" on the launchpad. Your Kerbals will panic if the "SAS" button is activated and its easier without this overly complicated technical things.

- Landing on Jool is mandatory before you even try to go to its moons.

Edited June 29, 2014 by blspblackdeath

As a newbie I found on launching:

-Best altitude for gravity turn is about 3,000 meters ASL.

-Optimal apoapsis for final Kerbin orbit is about 60,000 - 70,000 meters ASL.
When it comes to rovers, the faster the better. As long as you get your speed above 50 m/s, there is no chance of crashing. For unknown reasons, at this speed hitting 'B' crashes the game.
